The American ambivalence about race is best expressed in plain view in an old joke about Teddy Roosevelt as President and Booker T. Washington, the educator.

Mr. Washington met a man on horseback one day, who declared Mr. Washington to be "the greatest living American." Washington thanked him for his kind words, but expressed that the honor should belong to President Roosevelt. "I thought so too," the man replied. "Until he invited you to the White House for dinner."

Remember, this is a joke from the early 20th century, but the expression of the confused ambivalence of its attitudes and beliefs still mark the relationship between race and power.

There is virtually no ideological or other left in American politics.  There are many who are to the left of the extremists and corporate servants ruling over the Republican party.

You are correct.  I was thinking in relative terms; today's "left" is to the right of where the center used to be.  Nixon would have been too left today to find a home in the GOP or in the Democratic leadership.

There's more going on here than where people are on the ideological spectrum. The depth of adherence to ideology is more important. It drives politics. At the grass roots, the ideological left is more apt to stay home in primaries and mid-term elections. Meanwhile, the ideological right has spent the past few decades building up a formidable infrastructure of think tanks, lobbyists and pressure groups. They can turn on a dime to mobilize opposition to government actions they dislike - i.e., pretty much everything.

Let's also look at who runs for office. These days, you would be hard put to find a Republican candidate trying to appeal to liberals and moderates; most reflect the right or hard right, regardless of where they are running. Meanwhile, Democrats running in traditionally red or deep red areas often run as republican-lite. This sets up a skewed electorate, depriving voters in such areas of the kind of choice available elsewhere.

"I knew we'd get there eventually. God is good, God is compassionate, God loves the world..."

Nobody has directly affirmed that God is good, compassionate or loves the world -- certainly not I -- People often feel the need to ascribe certain characteristics to God which conform to their need for intellectual understanding and/or a sense of comfort.

"...but God can inflict smallpox upon people for inscrutable reasons of his own..."

Actually - Yes. God - being who He is - can do whatever He wants, whenever he wants to do it. There is plague in the O.T.

"...and then allow scientists to finally overcome it..."

Who knows what he does and does not "allow" ? - God, being who He is, exists on a plane which surpasses our ability to understand on an intellectual level -- which is one reason why people insist on attaching human characteristics to Him.

"...and it's none of my business to ask why..."

On the contrary -- you can certainly ask "why" - and you should present your question to God directly -- I've heard that He does answer the prayers and entreaties of those who seek knowledge of His ways.

"...just worship him, because otherwise, he's got even worse in store, is that it?..."

Umm - No, that's not it. Worship Him - or don't...either way God is still going to go about carrying on His business - whatever that may be.

It seem as if "your" God would never permit anyone to become ill and suffer - I suggest you check in with Him and see what He has to say about that.

Hi Evelyn,

I cannot provide the explanation that will get your attention, but perhaps I can give you hope to believe.

I don't pretend to know your religious views, however I'm curious why many agnostics and atheists are quite willing to ascribe to God creative powers to create smallpox, the black plague and other dastardly organisms, yet with unanimity deny Him the power of Creation and ascribe those powers to evolutionary theory? Why can they not ascribe to God the power of Creation and deadly viruses to evolution? This is a question worthy of contemplation.

I can offer the view that God did not create any virus. I don't know how they were created, but I can say that their utility and deadliness are entirely inconsistent with the character of God as portrayed by a full understanding of Biblical teaching. God loves you and your family and desires a close relationship with you. He is not mad with you and doesn't want to hurt you or anyone else. That kind of character is more consistent with Satan if you would entertain such a notion.

Perhaps at this point you're sure that I'm a loon and maybe I am. But I've had a personal experience with God and I know He's real. All I'd like to do is somehow try to offer you some hope through a different worldview for situations as hopeless as smallpox was before a vaccine was discovered. It's a much longer discussion than 1500 chars will allow.

I hope this post helps you find the hope you need to believe.

Best regards,
Blake

@Rima: All-too-true.  If certain parties/Parties who/that will not be named cannot even agree that these are truly "moral issues on which there can be no ambiguity" (to quote Mr. Blow) it's difficult to believe that we can find a mutually acceptable middle-ground on vitually anything else.  Insofar as reproductive rights are concerned, the only thing equivalent to an American position dictating that a woman should be denied the right to terminate a pregnancy is a Chinese position dictating that a woman should be denied the right to carry a fetus to term.

"There are some moral issues on which there can be no ambiguity." Mr. Blow incorrectly used the word "moral" when he meant "ethical." Equal rights, "reproductive options," and gun violence are all societal issues that we want to establish rules for, even if the rule is "let each individual decide for him or herself, according to one's morals." So to say "there can be no ambiguity" about these issues is to invite the same divisiveness he professes to abhor. "No ambiguity" equals "no discussion."

I agree with Anetliner Netliner that it is a language problem.

For example, Rima Regas' description of one side as "living and letting live" versus the other as "controlling how we all live" is exactly the kind of polarizing language that causes trouble. Neither phrase accurately and completely describes each "side," but I'll bet many people who read them agreed without a moment's thought.

The deeper meaning behind "on which there can be no ambiguity" is very troubling - regardless of which "side" says it.

@Citizen

The deeper meaning behind "there can be no ambiguity" when it comes to racism and the fact that we are all equal and equally deserving, is one that I wholeheartedly agree with and will spend a lifetime defending.

The deeper meaning behind "there can be no ambiguity" when it comes to women's right to self-determination is one with which I will spend a lifetime defending.

The deeper meaning behind "there can be no ambiguity" when it comes to the separation of church and state and freedom of and from religion is one which I will spend a lifetime defending.

The deeper meaning behind behind "there can be no ambiguity" when it comes to the right of citizens - all of them - to vote, is one which I will spend a lifetime defending.

Yes, there are some things that cannot be compromised and apply to all.

While I agree with Mr. Blow's policy positions on reproductive choice and gun control, I note that many would define an anti-abortion stance as a moral choice, and reasonably so. As to gun control, I would personally define it as a compelling policy issue, although I imagine that one could define it as a moral choice under a commitment to the "Thou shalt not kill" injunction in the Ten Commandments.

My feeling, though, is that Mr. Blow's characterization of these issues as moral issues feeds policy polarization and political impasse. It is far easier to find middle ground on tough political choices. It is harder to compromise on moral issues, and such language is part of the problem.

Lori, I understand your concern, I prefer  in class over distance learning too.  But for many of these people the choice is distance learning or no learning. When I was going to college (72-76) the tuition at Harvard was $1760 for the year. My state school, less than $600 for the year.  It meant someone with a single Pell Grant and a minimum wage summer job could get a degree and come out of school debt free. Today that's not possible. I much prefer them to have this than nothing, which is their options.

Dear Lori,

One of my friends is a stay-at-home mother and after a couple of years of caring for her children, she decided to take Open University courses. She got her degree within five years. It takes discipline, goal-orientedness and a very strong will to stick with this kind of independent work. For those who possess these prerequisites, Starbucks will make a great difference. For once, individual effort is to be rewarded.

We'd all like to start with a Porsche but affordability and uncertainties make most of us start with something more modest.  Let a pilot demonstrate the returns and make the case for measured upgrades.  This is a very generous move.  MOOCs and online options like University of Phoenix create their own communities.  They may be different from those of a traditional university but they do occur, and a population of 135,000 that is already part of a "community" (i.e., Starbucks' employees) is an alternative springboard for educational communities.

I'd rather this be for in-person classes. I am an educator myself, but it has yet to be proven that these on-line courses support retention over time. They certainly don't lead to community building, meaningful F2F conversation or other attributes of traditional education. I don't think the point of college is "taking" classes, it is engaging with and remembering material learned in classes.

I think the issue is more of mobility and opportunity. That's what a safety net is about - due to bad luck or some other circumstances, one can fall into poverty, but it should not be a permanent state. This is where well-designed programmes come in, to help the poor move up the social ladder - through work, but yes, also by helping them to get there.

The second unavoidable question is that of children. Being born into a poor family has huge consequneces on the outcome of these children's lives. But in a country with stronger social net and less income inequality, talented children have a way out (starting with free early school education, etc.). As a society, mobility is beneficial on the long run.

The players get millions, the owners get billions and they throw crumbs at the referees.  Remember the International referees retire at age 45!   Point of view of a Ref of over a 1000 adult and upper level youth matches.

In the Champion's League they now use 2 additional referees, parked behind the goal lines.  The WC should do this, too, as it adds an extra pair of eyes and ears where they are needed most: the box.  As a referee of 100s of youth games over 10+ years I can tell you that if you are close enough you can detect a flop and judge position.  The problem is, if you aren't close enough, you can't.  You hear contact, you see the force being applied.  Video replays show contact, but not force or true position. FIFA should add referees like the Champion's League has, already.  This will catch 95% of the fakes.
